tossups.question: The “Great Pumpkin” objection attacks a position named for this field that was co-developed by William Alston. Linda Zagzebski developed a neo-Aristotelian view in this field inspired by Ernest Sosa’s The Raft and the Pyramid. Alvin Plantinga’s “reformed” variant of this field holds certain claims to be “properly basic.” Susan Haack synthesized two major positions in this field as “foundherentism.” A paper in this field describes a (*) “case” in which Smith and Jones apply for the same job, and Jones has ten coins in his pocket. Edmund Gettier critiqued the Meno and Theaetetus’s definition of this field’s central concept as “justified true belief.” For 10 points, what field of philosophy is the study of knowledge?
tossups.question_sanitized: The "Great Pumpkin" objection attacks a position named for this field that was co-developed by William Alston. A paper in this field describes a (*) "case" in which Smith and Jones apply for the same job, and Jones has ten coins in his pocket. Edmund Gettier critiqued the Meno and Theaetetus's definition of this field's central concept as "justified true belief." For 10 points, what field of philosophy is the study of knowledge?
tossups.answer: epistemology [accept reformed epistemology; accept virtue epistemology; prompt on philosophy of knowledge until “knowledge” is read; prompt on belief or epistemic justification; prompt on philosophy until read]

tossups.question: Boethius defends the possibility of this property by analogizing God’s timelessness to the view from a mountain. Molinism holds that this property is possible because God has “middle knowledge” of counterfactuals. A theodicy named for this property argues that agents with this property are the source of evil, not God. Harry Frankfurt’s cases are counterexamples to the P·A·P, which states that a strong conception of this property is necessary for moral (*) responsibility. Theological fatalism argues that humans lack this property due to God’s infallible foreknowledge of our future. Compatibilism holds that determinism can coexist with this property. For 10 points, name this property of being able to choose one’s actions.
tossups.question_sanitized: Boethius defends the possibility of this property by analogizing God's timelessness to the view from a mountain. Molinism holds that this property is possible because God has "middle knowledge" of counterfactuals. A theodicy named for this property argues that agents with this property are the source of evil, not God. Harry Frankfurt's cases are counterexamples to the PAP, which states that a strong conception of this property is necessary for moral (*) responsibility. Theological fatalism argues that humans lack this property due to God's infallible foreknowledge of our future. Compatibilism holds that determinism can coexist with this property. For 10 points, name this property of being able to choose one's actions.
tossups.answer: free will [accept freedom of the will; accept libertarian free will or compatibilist free will]
tossups.answer_sanitized: free will [accept freedom of the will; accept libertarian free will or compatibilist free will]

tossups.question: This philosopher addressed the anti-slavery pamphlet “Emancipate Your Colonies!” to the French legislature. This philosopher argued that homosexuality does not “rob women” and should therefore be decriminalized in the essay “Offences Against One’s Self.” A controversial principle developed by this philosopher follows the dictates of mankind’s “two sovereign masters.” This philosopher developed the (*) “act” form of a philosophy that considers the intensity and duration of experiences as part of a felicific (“fel-ih-SIF-ik”) calculus. This philosopher formulated a moral theory that uses net pleasure and pain to calculate the greatest happiness for the greatest number. For 10 points, name this founder of utilitarianism.

This philosopher formulated a moral theory that uses net pleasure and pain to calculate the greatest happiness for the greatest number. For 10 points, name this founder of utilitarianism.
tossups.answer: Jeremy Bentham

tossups.question: Drawing on this thinker’s writings on ecology, John Bellamy Foster coined the term “metabolic rift.” Members of the September group, which included John Roemer and G. A. tossups.answer: Karl Marx

tossups.question: The earliest writings in this philosophical tradition were satirical poems called silloi written by Timon of Phlius. tossups.question: One of these texts encourages men to merge their speech with intellect by analogizing the path to wisdom to walking on a razor’s edge. These texts' idea that the soul unites with a life-force, or prana, at death heavily influenced Arthur Schopenhauer. The Katha and Isa are examples of these 108 Hindu texts. For 10 points, name these philosophical commentaries on the Vedas.

tossups.question: Neoplatonists identified this concept as the third hypostasis after the One and Nous, and believed that there was a “world” type of this concept similar to that described in the Timaeus. The just city shares the tripartite structure of this concept according to The (*) Republic, in which many of these concepts gather and are judged in the Myth of Er. tossups.question: This thinker’s metaphor of a tree of philosophy places the “most perfect moral system” on the highest branch. This thinker argued that the material world must exist due to our “great propensity” to believe that it causes our perceptions in a treatise’s sixth and final “day.” In a namesake “circle,” this thinker’s ontological proof of God relies on “clear and (*) distinct” perceptions that are only reliable by virtue of him. tossups.answer: René Descartes

tossups.question: Lena Halldenius reads this thinker’s character of Jemima as a critique of private property and places this thinker within the tradition of neo-Roman republicanism. Before Thomas Paine, this thinker identified liberty as non-domination and imagined dividing up large estates in a pamphlet responding to Edmund Burke’s Reflections. A treatise by this thinker derides advantageous marriages as “legal prostitution,” arguing instead for “friendship among equals.” That 1792 treatise by this thinker attacks the portrayal of (*) Sophie in Rousseau’s Emile and details a program of national education open to women. A Vindication of the Rights of Women is by, for 10 points, what early feminist philosopher and mother of Mary Shelley?
tossups.question_sanitized: Lena Halldenius reads this thinker's character of Jemima as a critique of private property and places this thinker within the tradition of neo-Roman republicanism. A treatise by this thinker derides advantageous marriages as "legal prostitution," arguing instead for "friendship among equals." That 1792 treatise by this thinker attacks the portrayal of (*) Sophie in Rousseau's Emile and details a program of national education open to women. A Vindication of the Rights of Women is by, for 10 points, what early feminist philosopher and mother of Mary Shelley?
tossups.answer: Mary Wollstonecraft (The pamphlet in the second line is A Vindication of the Rights of Men. Jemima is a character in Maria: Or, The Wrongs of Woman.)
tossups.answer_sanitized: Mary Wollstonecraft (The pamphlet in the second line is A Vindication of the Rights of Men. Jemima is a character in Maria: Or, The Wrongs of Woman.)

One thinker favored this concept “with danger” instead of “safety with slavery” shortly before imagining man (*) “everywhere…in chains.” The harm principle first appeared in a book titled for this concept by John Stuart Mill. Jean-Jacques Rousseau’s social contract involves protecting life, property, and, for 10 points, what concept representative of one’s freedom?
tossups.question_sanitized: An 1859 book titled for this concept analyzes physically stopping someone from crossing a compromised bridge as an example of a concept barred from "barbarians." This concept is "separate and equal" to the"Laws of Nature and of Nature's God" in the writings of John Locke. One thinker favored this concept "with danger" instead of "safety with slavery" shortly before imagining man (*) "everywhere...in chains." The harm principle first appeared in a book titled for this concept by John Stuart Mill. Jean-Jacques Rousseau's social contract involves protecting life, property, and, for 10 points, what concept representative of one's freedom?
tossups.answer: liberty [accept On Liberty; prompt on freedom; prompt on rights]
tossups.answer_sanitized: liberty [accept On Liberty; prompt on freedom; prompt on rights]

tossups.question: In a book titled for one of these people, Desiderius Erasmus argued against corporal punishment for students; that book is titled for the “Education of a Christian” one of these people. A genre of medieval political treatise is known as “mirrors for” these people. A text titled for one of these people claims Fortuna is a woman who must be (*) beaten and subdued. Lorenzo de Medici is the dedicatee of a text named for these people, which claims “it is better to be feared than loved.” For 10 points, Niccolo Machiavelli titled a political treatise after what kind of person?

For 10 points, Niccolo Machiavelli titled a political treatise after what kind of person?
tossups.answer: princes [accept The Education of a Christian Prince or Institutio principis Christiani; accept mirrors for princes or mirrors of princes or specula principum; accept The Prince or Il Principe or De Principatibus]

tossups.question: Gilles Deleuze (“jill-deloyz”) titled his secondary historical thesis for “Expressionism in Philosophy” and this thinker, and he referred to this thinker as the “Christ of philosophers” in a later work. Lewis Meyer is the addressee of this philosopher’s “Letter on the Infinite,” in which he discusses the concept of causa sui. This philosopher described the innate inclination of a thing to exist and enhance itself in his theory of (*) conatus. In one work, this philosopher rejects the “chosenness” of the Jewish people. This author of Tractatus Theologico-Politicus presented axioms in “geometric order” to systematically refute Cartesian dualism in his magnum opus. For 10 points, name this Jewish pantheist who equated God with Nature in Ethics.
tossups.answer: Baruch Spinoza
tossups.answer_sanitized: Baruch Spinoza

tossups.question: In a defense named for this concept, Alvin Plantinga termed the inevitable existence of sin as “transworld depravity.” Henri-Louis Bergson attacked Immanuel Kant’s position that this concept only exists outside of space and time in his doctoral thesis, which is titled for “Time and [this concept].” Harry Frankfurt argued that this concept is not required (*) to hold someone accountable for their actions in his refutation of the principle of alternate possibilities. A doctrine that seeks to reconcile this concept with its antithesis would be championed by John Stuart Mill and is known as compatibilism. For 10 points, name this concept often contrasted with causal (“caw-sul”) determinism that generally describes the ability to independently make decisions.
tossups.answer: free will
tossups.answer_sanitized: free will

tossups.question: This philosopher noted that empirical evidence cannot prove that Jesus is God through his concept of infinite qualitative distinction. A work by this thinker is presented by the editor Victor Eremita and concludes with the titular seducer manipulating Cordelia. This philosopher contrasted the sacrifices of Agamemnon and Abraham to define his concept of a (*) “leap of faith” in Philosophical Fragments; in that work’s Unscientific Postscript, this philosopher attacks Hegel’s Science of Logic and notably posits that “subjectivity is truth.” This philosopher contrasted the ethical and aesthetic spheres in a work published under the pseudonym Johannes Climachus. For 10 points, name this Danish philosopher who presented his existential philosophy in works such as The Concept of Anxiety and Either/Or.
tossups.answer: Søren Kierkegaard
tossups.answer_sanitized: Søren Kierkegaard

tossups.question: Susan Haack wrote a play titled for “[this philosopher] and Rorty in Conversation” in which she attacks the positions of the latter. This philosopher grouped logical predicates into three cenopythagorean categories of“Firstness,” “Secondness,” and “Thirdness.” This author of “On a New List of Categories” attacked the“method of tenacity” as being “unable to hold its ground (*) in practice” in another work. In an essay for Popular Science, this thinker criticized the existing “ornament of logic” and proposed that the goal of logic should be“clearness of apprehension.” For 10 points, name this American philosopher who wrote “The Fixation of Belief”and “How to Make Our Ideas Clear,” widely considered to be the Father of Pragmatism.
tossups.answer: C.S. Peirce (“purse”) [or Charles Sanders Peirce]
tossups.answer_sanitized: C.S. Peirce ("purse") [or Charles Sanders Peirce]
